title: Former WeWork CEO Adam Neumann Says He Has Regrets; In first interview since being ousted, Mr. Neumann said company's $47 billion valuation went to his head
text:
Mr. Neumann was ousted as CEO in fall 2019 after investors balked at WeWork's planned initial public offering. The company at one point sported a $47 billion valuation. But it underwent one of the most spectacular corporate meltdowns of the decade and aborted its IPO.

The company's valuation tumbled as prospective investors were turned off by its swelling losses, potential conflicts of interest and a perception of erratic leadership.

"So yes the valuation made us feel like we were right, which made me feel whatever style I was leading at, was a correct style at the time, so I do think it affected it," Mr. Neumann said, adding the chase went to his head.

"So when the whole world is telling you that," Mr. Neumann said about the company's valuation, "yes, we believed it and we thought it was really happening."

Mr. Neumann said that Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase & Co., personally advised him to step down from the company three days prior to his decision to do so. JPMorganwas underwriting WeWork's IPO in 2019.

"He told me, 'Adam, you have done a great job until now but you will have to put the company first,'" Mr. Neumann recounted. "I trusted Jamie and I looked up to Jamie. I still do," Mr. Neumann said.

JPMorgan didn't immediately respond to a request for Mr. Dimon to comment on Mr. Neumann's remarks.

WeWork Inc. made its debut last month on the New York Stock Exchange, capping a two-year journey following its failed IPO.

When Mr. Neumann left WeWork, he negotiated one of the largest-ever severance packages with WeWork investor SoftBank Group Corp. He received more than $198 million in payments from SoftBank, which includes money paid after a settlement earlier this year, while an entity he controls was able to sell $578 million in WeWork stock at a value above the opening day's closing share price of $11.78, according to regulatory filings.

To help clear the way for the public listing, he also negotiated with SoftBank to change the terms of a special stock award, entitling him to shares worth more than $200 million so long as WeWork's share price remains above $10, according to the filings.

Mr. Neumann also said he felt particularly regretful over the employees who were laid off by the company after his departure.

"This perception that as the company went from $47 billion valuation down to $9 [billion] and I profited somehow while the company is going down is completely false," he said.

Write to Talal Ansari at Talal.Ansari@wsj.com

Former WeWork CEO Adam Neumann Says He Has Regrets
